paper_title: ZnO-reduced graphene oxide nanocomposites as efficient photocatalysts for photocatalytic reduction of CO2

catalyst.source: The photocatalytic performance of the ZnO-rGO composites was investigated towards photoreduction of CO 2 to CH 3 OH.
catalyst.context: A series of zinc oxide/reduced graphene oxide nanocomposites (ZnO-rGO) were fabricated by a facile one-step hydrothermal method.The composite materials were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), Transmission scanning electron microscopy (TEM), Energy dispersive X-ray analysis (EDX), X-ray photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS), nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms, photoluminescence spectra (PL) and UVvis diffuse reflectance (DRS).The photocatalytic performance of the ZnO-rGO composites was investigated towards photoreduction of CO 2 to CH 3 OH.The yield of CH 3 OH on ZnO-rGO was five times as high as that on pure ZnO.The ZnO-rGO nanocomposites possess excellent reusing and cycling property.

catalyst.context: GO was prepared by a modified Hummers' method 25,26.In detail, 3 g graphite was put into a mixture of 15 mL H 2 SO 4 , 2.5 g K 2 S 2 O 8 , and 2.5 g P 2 O 5 .The solution was heated to 80 1C and kept stirring for 5 h in water bath.Then the mixture was diluted with 700 mL water, filtered and washed.The product was dried under room temperature.Thereafter, 15.0 g KMnO 4 was slowly added with magnetic stirring, to prevent the temperature of the mixture from exceeding 10 1C by ice bath.Then ice bath was then removed and the mixture was stirred at 35 1C for 2 h.The reaction was terminated by adding 800 mL of water and 25 mL H 2 O 2 solution.The mixture was filtered and washed with 1:10 HCl aqueous solution to remove metal ions followed by DI water to remove the acid.Finally, the GO was obtained by drying. The ZnO/rGO composites were prepared using a simple one-step hydrothermal method.In a typical synthesis, 3 mmol zinc nitrate was added to 60 mL deionized water and continuously stirred for 10 min.A certain amount of GO was added into the zinc nitrate solution and then it was sonicated for 1 h.Then, the pH value was adjusted to 8 by ammonia.After being stirred for 0.5 h, the obtained solution was sealed into a Teflon-lined autoclave and maintained at 160 1C for 10 h.Subsequently, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature naturally.The resulting samples were washed with deionized water and ethanol several times, and then dried in a vacuum oven under 50 1C for 8 h.A series of ZnO-rGO nanocomposites with different weight addition ratios of GO to nanocomposites (1, 5, 10, 20) were obtained.For comparison, the blank ZnO was prepared in the absence of GO using the same experimental conditions. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained using a D/MaxRB X-ray diffractometer (Japan) with Cu K irradiation source (1.5418A) through the 2 range from 51 to 801.The morphologies of the nanocomposites were done by a Japan transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM-1400).Energy dispersive X-ray spectrum of samples were obtained by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, HITACHI S-4800 combined with EDX).X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) data were taken by a Thermo ESCALAB250 system with a monochromatic Al K source and a charge neutralizer.The measurements of N 2 adsorption were carried out by using a USA Micromeritic ASAP 2020 nitrogen adsorption apparatus.Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectra of KBr powder-pressed pellets were recorded by Nicoletis 10 (China).The optical properties of the samples were characterized by a UV-2600 ultraviolet/visible diffuse reflectance spectrophotometer (DRS), during which BaSO 4 was employed as the internal reflectance standard.The photoluminescence spectra (PL) were recorded with a HITACHI F-2500 fluorescence spectrophotometer. The CO 2 reduction reaction was performed by using a quartz glass tube with a volume of 60 mL.A 300 W Xe lamp was used as the light source.First, 100 mg photocatalysts were added into 50 mL 1.0 M NaOH solution in the glass reactor with magnetic stirring.Then CO 2 gas was bubbled through the solution in the reactor for 0.5 h to remove the oxygen.The Xe lamp was turned on to start the photoreaction.During the reaction process, the liquid products were taken out per 45 min, then were centrifuged to remove catalysts.The concentration of methanol was analyzed by a gas chromatograph (GC-7900) equipped with a flame ionization detector and capillary column.Control experiments were carried out in the dark or without catalyst under the same experimental conditions.No methanol was detected in the absence of light irradiation or catalysts.

catalyst.source: Under UV-vis light irradiation, the assynthesized ZnO-rGO nanocomposite exhibits higher photocatalytic reduction efficiency than ZnO itself, in which the graphene sheets play an important role.
catalyst.context: The ZnO nanoparticles with a size of 5 25 nm are uniformly decorated on the rGO nanosheets through one-pot hydrothermal process.Under UV-vis light irradiation, the assynthesized ZnO-rGO nanocomposite exhibits higher photocatalytic reduction efficiency than ZnO itself, in which the graphene sheets play an important role.When the content of rGO was 10 and the dosage of photocatalyst was 2.0 g/L, ZnO-rGO nanocomposite displays the highest photocatalytic reduction activity.This work indicates that this sort of material could be used as a promising photocatalyst for the photoreduction of carbon dioxide. Fig. 1.XRD pattern of GO,ZnO and ZnO-10rGO. Fig. 3. (a) the C1s XPS spectra of GO and ZnO-rGO samples, (b) the Zn2p 3/2 XPS spectra of ZnO and ZnO-rGO samples. Fig. 4. FTIR spectra of GO and ZnO-10rGO samples. Fig. 5. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms and the corresponding pore-size distribution curves (inset) for the samples (a) ZnO and (b) ZnO-rGO. Fig. 6.(a) PL spectra of ZnO and ZnO-10rGO, (b) UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) of the samples of ZnO and ZnO-rGO. Fig. 7.The charge separation and transfer in the ZnO-rGO system for photoreduction of CO 2 to CH 3 OH. Fig.8(b) shows the yield of methanol on ZnO and ZnO-10 rGO catalysts under UV-vis light irradiation.It can be seen that, without rGO, pure ZnO has a lower property on methanol generation in the photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 compare with ZnO-10rGO.After three hours, the methanol yield of ZnO-10 rGO (263.17mol/g cat ) was about five times higher than that of pure ZnO (52.36 mol/g cat ).From above results, graphene have a positive impact on the photocatalytic performance of ZnO, which is attributed to the synergetic effects between ZnO nanoparticles and graphene nanosheets, this synergetic effect can improve the charge separation and the photocatalytic activity19,20.The amount of photocatalyst has a great effect on the photocatalytic activity for photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 .Different concentration of ZnO-10rGO catalyst (1 g/L, 1.5 g/L, 2 g/L, 2.5 g/L, 3 g/L) were investigated.As shown in Fig.8(c), the methanol yield increased gradually with increasing the concentration of ZnO-10rGO catalyst from 1 g/L to 2 g/L.It was reasonable that higher amount of photocatalyst can provide more active sites and absorb more light.However, further increase the concentration of ZnO-10rGO catalyst above 2 g/L, the methanol yield was decreased.Above result could conclude that excess photocatalysts will block the light penetration, consequently decreasing the photocatalytic activity. Fig. 8. (a) methanol yield of photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 over ZnO-rGO composites with different amounts of rGO after 3 h reaction under UV-vis light irradiation, (b) the methanol generation over ZnO-10rGO and pure ZnO under UV-vis light irradiation for 3 h, (c) effect of amount of photocatalyst on the yield of methanol (d) repeated photocatalytic reduction experiments under UV-vis light irradiation for 3 h. light source.context: The phase structure of the products was identified by powder XRD.Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of the GO, ZnO and ZnO-rGO composites.It can be seen that GO shows a diffraction peak (002) at a 2 value of 10.31, which indicates that most of the graphite power was oxidized into GO.The ZnO and ZnO-rGO samples present almost the same profiles and all the diffraction peaks match well to the hexagonal wurtzite ZnO (JCPDS no.36-1451).For ZnO-rGO composite, diffraction peak at 10.31 disappears and a weak and low intensity diffraction peak appears around 25.91, indicating the reduction of GO into rGO 27,28. The microstructure of the ZnO-rGO composites and GO was characterized using TEM in Fig. 2. As shown in Fig. 2(a), GO has 2D structure consisting of sheets with many wrinkles.From Fig. 2(b,c), numerous ZnO nanoparticles are observed on the surface of rGO sheets, which reveals a good combination of rGO and ZnO.Moreover, the profile of a single ZnO nanoparticle could be clearly distinguished, and ZnO nanoparticles are dispersed uniformly.Fig. 2(d) indicates that the obtained ZnO nanocrystals with the average diameter around 10.5 nm.The EDX spectrum of the ZnO-rGO composite (Fig. 2e) exhibits the presence of Zn, O and C in the material composition, which confirms the successful formation of ZnO-rGO composite 29. The XPS spectrum was applied to investigate the surface chemical states, composition change and interaction of ZnO with graphene.Fig. 3a shows the C1s spectra of GO and ZnO-rGO composites.The deconvoluted C1s XPS spectra of GO shows four different peaks located at 284.6 eV (C-C bonds), 286.7 eV (C-O bonds), 287.5 eV (C 14 O bonds), and 288.3 eV (O-C 14 O groups) 3,30.In contrast, the extremely loss of oxygen-containing carbonaceous peaks in ZnO-rGO composite is observed.This suggests that the GO was reduced after hydrothermal reaction 31.From Fig. 3b, compared to the Zn 2p 3/2 peak in pure ZnO, a shift towards higher binding energy of 1022.2 eV is observed in ZnO-rGO composite.This shift shows the absence of electrochemical interaction between ZnO and rGO, which can improve the catalytic activity of ZnO nanocrystal 29,30. The molecular structures of the prepared GO and ZnO-10 rGO were characterized by FTIR spectra, as shown in Fig. 4. For GO, the peaks at 3407, 1730, 1625, 1399, 1245, 1107 cm A 1 are due to the -OH stretching vibrations, C 14 O stretching vibrations, C 14 C configurable vibrations from the aromatic zooms, C-OH stretching vibrations, C-O stretching vibrations of epoxy, C-OH stretching vibrations 19,21.In ZnO-rGO, the intensities of these peaks decreased distinctly and even disappeared partly, which confirmed that most of oxygen-containing groups were removed.This result also indicates that GO was reduced effectively through hydrothermal process.The absorption peak of CC appears around 1565 cm A 1 was the skeletal vibration of graphene 32.And the obvious peak at 460 cm A 1 can be ascribed to the stretching vibration of Zn-O 19. The N 2 adsorption A desorption isotherms(in Fig. 5) were recorded to investigate the BET surface area and pore structure of ZnO and ZnO-rGO composite.In Fig. 5a the isotherm of ZnO is of type II (BDDT) with a wide pore size distribution in the mesoporous and macroporous regions 32.The specific surface area of ZnO is calculated to be 2.7989 m 2 g A 1 .For comparison, the isotherm of ZnO-rGO composite (in Fig. 5b) shows typical type IV behavior with H 3 hysteresis-loop, which is associated with slit-like pores formed by the stacking of the ZnO-rGO composite sheets 33.According to the pore size distribution (inset), the ZnO-rGO composite has obvious mesopores with a peak pore diameter of around 3 nm and decreased amount of macropores compared with pure ZnO.The porous structure of ZnO-rGO composite can facilitate the adsorption of reactants and transportation of products.The BET specific surface area of ZnO-rGO composite can reach up to 23.6863 m 2 g A 1 , which is much higher than that of the pure ZnO.The larger specific surface area can provide more surface active sites and facilitate the migration of charge carriers, which is remarkable useful to improve the photocatalytic performance 3. The change of electron or energy transfer between ZnO and rGO was detected by photoluminescence (PL) measurements.Fig. 6(a) shows the PL spectra of ZnO and ZnO-10rGO.ZnO displays a broad PL emission peak at around 603 nm.As expected, ZnO-10rGO shows a significant decrease in the intensity of PL compared to ZnO.The weaker intensity of the peak represents the lower recombination probability of free charges, which indicates that coupling with rGO can effectively mitigate the recombination of photogenerated electronhole pairs of ZnO 20,29. The UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) were measured to investigate the optical properties of synthesized samples, as shown in Fig. 6(b).It is clear that pure ZnO can mainly absorb ultraviolet light.However, all ZnO-rGO samples present an enhanced absorption over pure ZnO in the visible light region, and the characteristic absorption edges display a slight red shift.The results show that the introduction of rGO extends the light response range and enhances the utilization of solar energy 29.The similar phenomenon also can be observed from other graphene-based semiconductor nanomaterials 3,21. ZnO-rGO nanocomposites and pure ZnO are used as photocatalysts to evaluate the photocatalytic activity by photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 into methanol.The charge separation and transfer in the reaction system was shown in Fig. 7.Under UV-vis light irradiation, the excited electrons jump from the valence band (VB) of ZnO nanocrystal to its conduction band (CB), but these electrons can combine with holes quickly.In ZnO-rGO nanocomposites, due to the interaction between ZnO nanocrystal and graphene nanosheet, the electrons from ZnO can easily transfer to the surface of graphene and delay the combination of electron and hole.Holes in the valence band of ZnO react with water producing O 2 and H .Absorbed CO 2 molecules are reduced to methanol by enriched electrons on the graphene surface.During the reduction process, the major reaction steps were described briefly as follows. From Fig. 8(a), the content of rGO has an significant effect on the photocatalytic activity of ZnO nanocrystal.The order of methanol yield depended on the content of GO was ZnO-10 rGO4ZnO-5rGO4ZnO-20rGO4ZnO-1rGO.The highest yield of methanol over ZnO-rGO was 263.17 mol/g cat when the mass fraction of GO in composite was 10.Further increasing the content of GO, the catalytic activity decreased, which was probably due to the fact that more graphene would prevent light from reaching surface of ZnO nanoparticles and reduce the generation of electrons and holes, thereby decreasing the reduction of CO 2 34.shows the yield of methanol on ZnO and ZnO-10 rGO catalysts under UV-vis light irradiation.It can be seen that, without rGO, pure ZnO has a lower property on methanol generation in the photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 compare with ZnO-10rGO.After three hours, the methanol yield of ZnO-10 rGO (263.17mol/g cat ) was about five times higher than that of pure ZnO (52.36 mol/g cat ).From above results, graphene have a positive impact on the photocatalytic performance of ZnO, which is attributed to the synergetic effects between ZnO nanoparticles and graphene nanosheets, this synergetic effect can improve the charge separation and the photocatalytic activity 19,20. The amount of photocatalyst has a great effect on the photocatalytic activity for photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 .Different concentration of ZnO-10rGO catalyst (1 g/L, 1.5 g/L, 2 g/L, 2.5 g/L, 3 g/L) were investigated.As shown in Fig. 8(c), the methanol yield increased gradually with increasing the concentration of ZnO-10rGO catalyst from 1 g/L to 2 g/L.It was reasonable that higher amount of photocatalyst can provide more active sites and absorb more light.However, further increase the concentration of ZnO-10rGO catalyst above 2 g/L, the methanol yield was decreased.Above result could conclude that excess photocatalysts will block the light penetration, consequently decreasing the photocatalytic activity. The stability of ZnO-rGO was researched by performing the photocatalytic reduction experiment repeatedly three times under the same reaction condition.As shown in Fig. 8(d), there was a little change in amount of obtained methanol, and the total yield of methanol on ZnO-10rGO was decreased only 5.The results demonstrated that this kind of photocatalyst is a promising candidate for environmental management.

FTIR spectra of GO and ZnO-10rGO samples. Fig. 5. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms and the corresponding pore-size distribution curves (inset) for the samples (a) ZnO and (b) ZnO-rGO. Fig. 6.(a) PL spectra of ZnO and ZnO-10rGO, (b) UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) of the samples of ZnO and ZnO-rGO. Fig. 7.The charge separation and transfer in the ZnO-rGO system for photoreduction of CO 2 to CH 3 OH. Fig.8(b) shows the yield of methanol on ZnO and ZnO-10 rGO catalysts under UV-vis light irradiation.It can be seen that, without rGO, pure ZnO has a lower property on methanol generation in the photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 compare with ZnO-10rGO.After three hours, the methanol yield of ZnO-10 rGO (263.17mol/g cat ) was about five times higher than that of pure ZnO (52.36 mol/g cat ).From above results, graphene have a positive impact on the photocatalytic performance of ZnO, which is attributed to the synergetic effects between ZnO nanoparticles and graphene nanosheets, this synergetic effect can improve the charge separation and the photocatalytic activity19,20.The amount of photocatalyst has a great effect on the photocatalytic activity for photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 .Different concentration of ZnO-10rGO catalyst (1 g/L, 1.5 g/L, 2 g/L, 2.5 g/L, 3 g/L) were investigated.As shown in Fig.8(c), the methanol yield increased gradually with increasing the concentration of ZnO-10rGO catalyst from 1 g/L to 2 g/L.It was reasonable that higher amount of photocatalyst can provide more active sites and absorb more light.However, further increase the concentration of ZnO-10rGO catalyst above 2 g/L, the methanol yield was decreased.Above result could conclude that excess photocatalysts will block the light penetration, consequently decreasing the photocatalytic activity. lamp.source: A 300 W Xe lamp was used as the light source.
lamp.context: GO was prepared by a modified Hummers' method 25,26.In detail, 3 g graphite was put into a mixture of 15 mL H 2 SO 4 , 2.5 g K 2 S 2 O 8 , and 2.5 g P 2 O 5 .The solution was heated to 80 1C and kept stirring for 5 h in water bath.Then the mixture was diluted with 700 mL water, filtered and washed.The product was dried under room temperature.Thereafter, 15.0 g KMnO 4 was slowly added with magnetic stirring, to prevent the temperature of the mixture from exceeding 10 1C by ice bath.Then ice bath was then removed and the mixture was stirred at 35 1C for 2 h.The reaction was terminated by adding 800 mL of water and 25 mL H 2 O 2 solution.The mixture was filtered and washed with 1:10 HCl aqueous solution to remove metal ions followed by DI water to remove the acid.Finally, the GO was obtained by drying. The ZnO/rGO composites were prepared using a simple one-step hydrothermal method.In a typical synthesis, 3 mmol zinc nitrate was added to 60 mL deionized water and continuously stirred for 10 min.A certain amount of GO was added into the zinc nitrate solution and then it was sonicated for 1 h.Then, the pH value was adjusted to 8 by ammonia.After being stirred for 0.5 h, the obtained solution was sealed into a Teflon-lined autoclave and maintained at 160 1C for 10 h.Subsequently, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature naturally.The resulting samples were washed with deionized water and ethanol several times, and then dried in a vacuum oven under 50 1C for 8 h.A series of ZnO-rGO nanocomposites with different weight addition ratios of GO to nanocomposites (1, 5, 10, 20) were obtained.For comparison, the blank ZnO was prepared in the absence of GO using the same experimental conditions. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained using a D/MaxRB X-ray diffractometer (Japan) with Cu K irradiation source (1.5418A) through the 2 range from 51 to 801.The morphologies of the nanocomposites were done by a Japan transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM-1400).Energy dispersive X-ray spectrum of samples were obtained by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, HITACHI S-4800 combined with EDX).X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) data were taken by a Thermo ESCALAB250 system with a monochromatic Al K source and a charge neutralizer.The measurements of N 2 adsorption were carried out by using a USA Micromeritic ASAP 2020 nitrogen adsorption apparatus.Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectra of KBr powder-pressed pellets were recorded by Nicoletis 10 (China).The optical properties of the samples were characterized by a UV-2600 ultraviolet/visible diffuse reflectance spectrophotometer (DRS), during which BaSO 4 was employed as the internal reflectance standard.The photoluminescence spectra (PL) were recorded with a HITACHI F-2500 fluorescence spectrophotometer. The CO 2 reduction reaction was performed by using a quartz glass tube with a volume of 60 mL.A 300 W Xe lamp was used as the light source.First, 100 mg photocatalysts were added into 50 mL 1.0 M NaOH solution in the glass reactor with magnetic stirring.Then CO 2 gas was bubbled through the solution in the reactor for 0.5 h to remove the oxygen.The Xe lamp was turned on to start the photoreaction.During the reaction process, the liquid products were taken out per 45 min, then were centrifuged to remove catalysts.The concentration of methanol was analyzed by a gas chromatograph (GC-7900) equipped with a flame ionization detector and capillary column.Control experiments were carried out in the dark or without catalyst under the same experimental conditions.No methanol was detected in the absence of light irradiation or catalysts.

reaction medium.source: Holes in the valence band of ZnO react with water producing O 2 and H .Absorbed CO 2 molecules are reduced to methanol by enriched electrons on the graphene surface.
reaction medium.context: The phase structure of the products was identified by powder XRD.Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of the GO, ZnO and ZnO-rGO composites.It can be seen that GO shows a diffraction peak (002) at a 2 value of 10.31, which indicates that most of the graphite power was oxidized into GO.The ZnO and ZnO-rGO samples present almost the same profiles and all the diffraction peaks match well to the hexagonal wurtzite ZnO (JCPDS no.36-1451).For ZnO-rGO composite, diffraction peak at 10.31 disappears and a weak and low intensity diffraction peak appears around 25.91, indicating the reduction of GO into rGO 27,28. The microstructure of the ZnO-rGO composites and GO was characterized using TEM in Fig. 2. As shown in Fig. 2(a), GO has 2D structure consisting of sheets with many wrinkles.From Fig. 2(b,c), numerous ZnO nanoparticles are observed on the surface of rGO sheets, which reveals a good combination of rGO and ZnO.Moreover, the profile of a single ZnO nanoparticle could be clearly distinguished, and ZnO nanoparticles are dispersed uniformly.Fig. 2(d) indicates that the obtained ZnO nanocrystals with the average diameter around 10.5 nm.The EDX spectrum of the ZnO-rGO composite (Fig. 2e) exhibits the presence of Zn, O and C in the material composition, which confirms the successful formation of ZnO-rGO composite 29. The XPS spectrum was applied to investigate the surface chemical states, composition change and interaction of ZnO with graphene.Fig. 3a shows the C1s spectra of GO and ZnO-rGO composites.The deconvoluted C1s XPS spectra of GO shows four different peaks located at 284.6 eV (C-C bonds), 286.7 eV (C-O bonds), 287.5 eV (C 14 O bonds), and 288.3 eV (O-C 14 O groups) 3,30.In contrast, the extremely loss of oxygen-containing carbonaceous peaks in ZnO-rGO composite is observed.This suggests that the GO was reduced after hydrothermal reaction 31.From Fig. 3b, compared to the Zn 2p 3/2 peak in pure ZnO, a shift towards higher binding energy of 1022.2 eV is observed in ZnO-rGO composite.This shift shows the absence of electrochemical interaction between ZnO and rGO, which can improve the catalytic activity of ZnO nanocrystal 29,30. The molecular structures of the prepared GO and ZnO-10 rGO were characterized by FTIR spectra, as shown in Fig. 4. For GO, the peaks at 3407, 1730, 1625, 1399, 1245, 1107 cm A 1 are due to the -OH stretching vibrations, C 14 O stretching vibrations, C 14 C configurable vibrations from the aromatic zooms, C-OH stretching vibrations, C-O stretching vibrations of epoxy, C-OH stretching vibrations 19,21.In ZnO-rGO, the intensities of these peaks decreased distinctly and even disappeared partly, which confirmed that most of oxygen-containing groups were removed.This result also indicates that GO was reduced effectively through hydrothermal process.The absorption peak of CC appears around 1565 cm A 1 was the skeletal vibration of graphene 32.And the obvious peak at 460 cm A 1 can be ascribed to the stretching vibration of Zn-O 19. The N 2 adsorption A desorption isotherms(in Fig. 5) were recorded to investigate the BET surface area and pore structure of ZnO and ZnO-rGO composite.In Fig. 5a the isotherm of ZnO is of type II (BDDT) with a wide pore size distribution in the mesoporous and macroporous regions 32.The specific surface area of ZnO is calculated to be 2.7989 m 2 g A 1 .For comparison, the isotherm of ZnO-rGO composite (in Fig. 5b) shows typical type IV behavior with H 3 hysteresis-loop, which is associated with slit-like pores formed by the stacking of the ZnO-rGO composite sheets 33.According to the pore size distribution (inset), the ZnO-rGO composite has obvious mesopores with a peak pore diameter of around 3 nm and decreased amount of macropores compared with pure ZnO.The porous structure of ZnO-rGO composite can facilitate the adsorption of reactants and transportation of products.The BET specific surface area of ZnO-rGO composite can reach up to 23.6863 m 2 g A 1 , which is much higher than that of the pure ZnO.The larger specific surface area can provide more surface active sites and facilitate the migration of charge carriers, which is remarkable useful to improve the photocatalytic performance 3. The change of electron or energy transfer between ZnO and rGO was detected by photoluminescence (PL) measurements.Fig. 6(a) shows the PL spectra of ZnO and ZnO-10rGO.ZnO displays a broad PL emission peak at around 603 nm.As expected, ZnO-10rGO shows a significant decrease in the intensity of PL compared to ZnO.The weaker intensity of the peak represents the lower recombination probability of free charges, which indicates that coupling with rGO can effectively mitigate the recombination of photogenerated electronhole pairs of ZnO 20,29. The UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) were measured to investigate the optical properties of synthesized samples, as shown in Fig. 6(b).It is clear that pure ZnO can mainly absorb ultraviolet light.However, all ZnO-rGO samples present an enhanced absorption over pure ZnO in the visible light region, and the characteristic absorption edges display a slight red shift.The results show that the introduction of rGO extends the light response range and enhances the utilization of solar energy 29.The similar phenomenon also can be observed from other graphene-based semiconductor nanomaterials 3,21. ZnO-rGO nanocomposites and pure ZnO are used as photocatalysts to evaluate the photocatalytic activity by photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 into methanol.The charge separation and transfer in the reaction system was shown in Fig. 7.Under UV-vis light irradiation, the excited electrons jump from the valence band (VB) of ZnO nanocrystal to its conduction band (CB), but these electrons can combine with holes quickly.In ZnO-rGO nanocomposites, due to the interaction between ZnO nanocrystal and graphene nanosheet, the electrons from ZnO can easily transfer to the surface of graphene and delay the combination of electron and hole.Holes in the valence band of ZnO react with water producing O 2 and H .Absorbed CO 2 molecules are reduced to methanol by enriched electrons on the graphene surface.During the reduction process, the major reaction steps were described briefly as follows. From Fig. 8(a), the content of rGO has an significant effect on the photocatalytic activity of ZnO nanocrystal.The order of methanol yield depended on the content of GO was ZnO-10 rGO4ZnO-5rGO4ZnO-20rGO4ZnO-1rGO.The highest yield of methanol over ZnO-rGO was 263.17 mol/g cat when the mass fraction of GO in composite was 10.Further increasing the content of GO, the catalytic activity decreased, which was probably due to the fact that more graphene would prevent light from reaching surface of ZnO nanoparticles and reduce the generation of electrons and holes, thereby decreasing the reduction of CO 2 34.shows the yield of methanol on ZnO and ZnO-10 rGO catalysts under UV-vis light irradiation.It can be seen that, without rGO, pure ZnO has a lower property on methanol generation in the photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 compare with ZnO-10rGO.After three hours, the methanol yield of ZnO-10 rGO (263.17mol/g cat ) was about five times higher than that of pure ZnO (52.36 mol/g cat ).From above results, graphene have a positive impact on the photocatalytic performance of ZnO, which is attributed to the synergetic effects between ZnO nanoparticles and graphene nanosheets, this synergetic effect can improve the charge separation and the photocatalytic activity 19,20. The amount of photocatalyst has a great effect on the photocatalytic activity for photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 .Different concentration of ZnO-10rGO catalyst (1 g/L, 1.5 g/L, 2 g/L, 2.5 g/L, 3 g/L) were investigated.As shown in Fig. 8(c), the methanol yield increased gradually with increasing the concentration of ZnO-10rGO catalyst from 1 g/L to 2 g/L.It was reasonable that higher amount of photocatalyst can provide more active sites and absorb more light.However, further increase the concentration of ZnO-10rGO catalyst above 2 g/L, the methanol yield was decreased.Above result could conclude that excess photocatalysts will block the light penetration, consequently decreasing the photocatalytic activity. The stability of ZnO-rGO was researched by performing the photocatalytic reduction experiment repeatedly three times under the same reaction condition.As shown in Fig. 8(d), there was a little change in amount of obtained methanol, and the total yield of methanol on ZnO-10rGO was decreased only 5.The results demonstrated that this kind of photocatalyst is a promising candidate for environmental management.
